title: 107_hr4005
content: The Act is titled the "District of Columbia and United States Territories Circulating Quarter Dollar Program Act" and involves the issuance of redesigned quarter dollars commemorating the District of Columbia and each of the territories. Section 5112 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to include a new subsection for the redesign and issuance of circulating quarter dollars commemorating the District of Columbia and the territories in 2009. The designs on the reverse side of the coins will be emblematic of the District of Columbia and the territories, with flexibility in the placement of inscriptions. The redesign and issuance of circulating quarter dollars in 2009 will feature inscriptions on the reverse side and designs emblematic of the District of Columbia and various territories. The redesign and issuance of circulating quarter dollars in 2009 will feature inscriptions on the reverse side and designs emblematic of the District of Columbia and various territories. The selection of designs for quarter dollars will be done by the Secretary after consultation with relevant officials and the Commission of Fine Arts. Designs may be submitted following a specific design selection and approval process. The Secretary has the sole discretion in the design selection and approval process for the Nation's coinage and currency. Participation may include District or territorial officials, artists, engravers, and members of the public. The Secretary is prohibited from selecting frivolous or inappropriate designs for quarter dollars. No head and shoulders portrait or bust of any person is allowed. The Secretary has the sole discretion in selecting and approving coin designs, with participation from various individuals. Designs for quarter dollars cannot include head and shoulders portraits of living persons. Coins minted under this subsection are considered numismatic items and can be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities. The Secretary may also mint silver quarter dollars. The Secretary has the discretion to select and approve coin designs for quarter dollars, with restrictions on portraits of living persons. Coins minted under this subsection are considered numismatic items and can be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities. The Secretary may also mint silver quarter dollars with 90 percent silver and 10 percent copper content sourced from available resources. Coins commemorating the District of Columbia and territories will be issued in equal intervals during 2009 in a specific order. The subsection discusses the application of provisions in the event of admission as a state or independence for territories like the District of Columbia. The subsection defines territories like Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, US Virgin Islands, and Northern Mariana Islands. It states that certain provisions will cease to apply if these territories are admitted as a state or gain independence. The House of Representatives passed the legislation on October 7, 2002.
